data.title: A Law University Interview Template
data.meta_description: Explore Bristol Law School through our detailed guide, highlighting past questions, interview tips, and admissions statistics. Enhance your application tactics
data.text:
The course at Bristol is described by the university as being an ‘intellectually demanding, research-rich curriculum will spark your passion for a subject that opens doors to top-flight careers in both law and non-law sectors.’ This means that it includes numerous different units to choose from, reflecting the expertise of its teaching staff. As a guide, first year units will begin the process of you analysing, writing, and arguing like a lawyer. The Law in Action unit ‘provides an exciting introduction to essential knowledge and skills needed for effective study of law at university.’

Second and third year units will allow students more flexibility to focus on topics that interest them – these units include anything from banking and finance to IT, from international and commercial law to health and human rights law. You can also take the Clinical Legal Studies option which provides real-life experience. You will also undertake a final year research project.

Bristol interviews in two situations: if you apply with non-standard qualifications, or if you are a mature student. The interview will be conducted by at least two people, and one of them will have been trained in ‘fair and effective recruitment techniques.’ If you are to be offered an interview you will be contacted by the university with a date.

The interview is designed to assess the following domains:

– Interest in the subject, suitability for it, and commitment to it

– Evidence of ability to think clearly, to understand, to solve problems, and to analyse

– High standard of spoken English

– Appropriateness of the course in relation to the applicant’s aspirations and interests

– Non-academic achievements and experiences that show the candidate will contribute to the university

– Positions of responsibility

– Any other relevant skills

The university states that it will aim to contact you with the outcome of your interview within two weeks of sitting it. However, this may take a little longer in some cases. However, despite this they further state that ‘while you will likely hear from us within this time period, it is unlikely we will offer you a place on the course until after all of our interviews are completed.’ This is to ensure that all applicants are treated equally.

Interest in the Subject, Suitability for It, and Commitment to It:

What inspired you to study law at the university level?

How do your academic background and personal interests align with your decision to study law?

What specific areas of law are you most interested in and why?

Can you discuss a recent legal development that has captured your attention?

How do you plan to stay committed and engaged throughout your legal studies?

Evidence of Ability to Think Clearly, to Understand, to Solve Problems, and to Analyse:

Describe a complex problem you have encountered and the steps you took to solve it.

How do you approach evaluating conflicting viewpoints or evidence when forming an argument?

Can you provide an example of a situation where you needed to apply critical thinking skills to make a decision?

How do you ensure your analysis remains objective and unbiased when exploring controversial topics?

Describe a challenging project or assignment you completed that demonstrates your problem-solving abilities.

High Standard of Spoken English:

How have you developed your English communication skills in academic or professional settings?

Can you provide an example of a presentation or public speaking experience that showcases your proficiency in spoken English?

How do you tailor your communication style to ensure clarity and comprehension for different audiences?

Describe a situation where you had to effectively communicate complex information to someone unfamiliar with the topic.

What strategies do you use to continuously improve your spoken English skills?

Appropriateness of the Course in Relation to the Applicant’s Aspirations and Interests:

How does Bristol University’s law program align with your career goals and personal interests?

What aspects of Bristol University’s law program make it the right fit for you?

How do you plan to use the resources and opportunities available at Bristol University to further your legal education?

Can you discuss any specific courses or extracurricular activities offered by Bristol University that particularly interest you?
